paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Working with HDFS
**Objective:** Learn to use HDFS -- the Hadoop Distributed File System -- via the HDFS command line interface
**File locations:** /home/devuser/data/telco/activations/
**Successful outcome:** 
**Before you begin:** N/A
**Related lessons:** 

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Working with HDFS
Objective: Learn to use HDFS – the Hadoop Distributed File System – via the HDFS command line interface
File locations: /home/devuser/data/telco/activations/
Successful outcome:
Before you begin: N/A
Related lessons:
Setup
Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface

msg.data: Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface

paragraphs.title: 1 - List the content of the HDFS root directory
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the HDFS command line to list the content of the HDFS root directory.

There will be multiple entries, one of which is `/user`. Each user has a "home" directory under the user directory, named after their username; your user the exercises for this course will be **zeppelin**, therefore your home directory is `/user/zeppelin`.

msg.data:
Use the HDFS command line to list the content of the HDFS root directory.
There will be multiple entries, one of which is /user. Each user has a “home” directory under the user directory, named after their username; your user the exercises for this course will be zeppelin, therefore your home directory is /user/zeppelin.

Found 13 items
drwxrwxrwt   - yarn   hadoop          0 2020-06-07 20:50 /app-logs
drwxr-xr-x   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:15 /apps
drwxr-xr-x   - yarn   hadoop          0 2020-06-07 20:14 /ats
drwxr-xr-x   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:15 /atsv2
drwxrwxrwx   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 21:05 /data
drwxr-xr-x   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:15 /hdp
drwxr-xr-x   - mapred hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:14 /mapred
drwxrwxrwx   - mapred hadoop          0 2020-06-07 20:15 /mr-history
drwxr-xr-x   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:15 /services
drwxrwxrwx   - spark  hadoop          0 2020-06-10 17:24 /spark2-history
drwxrwxrwx   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 22:24 /tmp
drwxr-xr-x   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 21:05 /user
drwxr-xr-x   - hdfs   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:16 /warehouse

paragraphs.title: 2 - View the contents of the /user directory
paragraphs.text:
%md
You will see your working directory -- `zeppelin` -- in the listing.

>**Relative Paths**
In HDFS, relative (non-absolute) paths are considered relative
to your home directory. There is no concept of a "current" or
"working" directory as there is in Linux and similar filesystems.

msg.data:
You will see your working directory – zeppelin – in the listing.

Relative Paths
In HDFS, relative (non-absolute) paths are considered relative
to your home directory. There is no concept of a “current” or
“working” directory as there is in Linux and similar filesystems.

Found 8 items
drwxrwx---   - ambari-qa hdfs            0 2020-06-07 22:11 /user/ambari-qa
drwxr-xr-x   - devuser   hdfs            0 2020-06-07 21:05 /user/devuser
drwxr-xr-x   - hbase     hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:14 /user/hbase
drwxr-xr-x   - hive      hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:51 /user/hive
drwxrwxr-x   - spark     hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:17 /user/spark
drwxr-xr-x   - sysadmin  hdfs            0 2020-06-07 21:05 /user/sysadmin
drwxrwx---   - yarn-ats  hadoop          0 2020-06-07 20:16 /user/yarn-ats
drwxrwxrwx   - zeppelin  hdfs            0 2020-06-07 20:15 /user/zeppelin

paragraphs.title: 3 - List the contents of your home directory
paragraphs.text:
%md
List the contents of your home directory.

Note that the directory structure in HDFS is unrelated to the directory structure of
the local filesystem on the remote host; they are completely separate namespaces.

msg.data:
List the contents of your home directory by running:

$ hdfs dfs -ls /user/training

Note that the directory structure in HDFS is unrelated to the directory structure of
the local filesystem on the remote host; they are completely separate namespaces.

Found 3 items
drwxrwxrwx   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-06-10 03:20 /user/zeppelin/conf
drwxrwxrwx   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-06-10 03:20 /user/zeppelin/notebook
drwxrwxrwx   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-06-07 20:15 /user/zeppelin/test

paragraphs.title: 4 - View the directory of course resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
If you perform a regular Linux `ls` command on the directory `~/data/telco/`, you will see several files and directories that will be used in this course.

msg.data:
Change directories to the Linux local filesystem directory containing sample data
you will be using in the course.

$ cd $DEVDATA

If you perform a regular Linux ls command in this directory, you will see several files and directories that will be used in this course.

accountdevice
activations
activations_stream
base_stations.parquet
devices.csv
devices.json
devicestatus_stream
devicestatus_stream.txt
devicestatus.txt
frostroad.txt
kb
loudacre.sql
makes1.txt
makes2.txt
static_data
weblogs
writedevicestatus-devsh.py

paragraphs.title: 5  - Insert the activations directory into HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
Copy the local `activations` directory and its contents into a remote HDFS directory named `/user/zeppelin/activations`.

msg.data:
$ hdfs dfs -put activations /devsh_loudacre/

This copies the local activations directory and its contents into a remote HDFS
directory named /devsh_loudacre/activations.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Confirm the upload by listing the contents of the new directory

paragraphs.title: 7 - View some of the data you just copied into HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
An individual file is often very large, making it inconvenient to view the entire file in the terminal. For this reason, it is often a good idea to pipe the output of the `dfs -cat` command into `head`, `more`, or `less`. You can also use `hdfs dfs -head` to more efficiently view the end of the file, rather than piping the whole content. You can specify the number of lines you want the `-head` command to print, as shown in the following command. 

This prints the first 20 lines of the article to your terminal. This command is handy for viewing text data in HDFS. 

**Note:** You may see a warning: `cat: Unable to write to output stream`. This is because the `cat` was only able to pipe the first 20 lines because of the limit specified in the head command. You can disregard the warning.

msg.data:
This prints the first 20 lines of the article to your terminal. This command is handy for viewing text data in HDFS. An individual file is often very large, making it inconvenient to view the entire file in the terminal. For this reason, it is often a good idea to pipe the output of the dfs -cat command into head, more, or less. You can also use hdfs dfs -tail to more efficiently view the end of the file, rather than piping the whole content.

Note: You may see a warning: cat: Unable to write to output stream. This is because the cat was only able to pipe the first 20 lines because of the limit specified in the head command. You can disregard the warning.

paragraphs.title: 11 - Familiarize yourself with the operations available with the hdfs dfs command
paragraphs.text:
%md
There are several other operations available with the `hdfs dfs` command to
perform most common filesystem manipulations such as `mv`, `cp`, and `mkdir`.

Using the `hdfs dfs` command with no arguments will display the available
commands.

Optional: Continue exploring the HDFS filesystem by experimenting with some of
these commands.

msg.data:
There are several other operations available with the hdfs dfs command to
perform most common filesystem manipulations such as mv, cp, and mkdir.

Using the hdfs dfs command with no arguments will display the available
commands.

$ hdfs dfs

Optional: Continue exploring the HDFS filesystem by experimenting with some of
these commands.

Usage: hadoop fs [generic options]
	[-appendToFile <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-cat [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-checksum <src> ...]
	[-chgrp [-R] GROUP PATH...]
	[-chmod [-R] <MODE[,MODE]... | OCTALMODE> PATH...]
	[-chown [-R] [OWNER][:[GROUP]] PATH...]
	[-copyFromLocal [-f] [-p] [-l] [-d] [-t <thread count>] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-copyToLocal [-f] [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-count [-q] [-h] [-v] [-t [<storage type>]] [-u] [-x] [-e] <path> ...]
	[-cp [-f] [-p | -p[topax]] [-d] <src> ... <dst>]
	[-createSnapshot <snapshotDir> [<snapshotName>]]
	[-deleteSnapshot <snapshotDir> <snapshotName>]
	[-df [-h] [<path> ...]]
	[-du [-s] [-h] [-v] [-x] <path> ...]
	[-expunge]
	[-find <path> ... <expression> ...]
	[-get [-f] [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-getfacl [-R] <path>]
	[-getfattr [-R] {-n name | -d} [-e en] <path>]
	[-getmerge [-nl] [-skip-empty-file] <src> <localdst>]
	[-head <file>]
	[-help [cmd ...]]
	[-ls [-C] [-d] [-h] [-q] [-R] [-t] [-S] [-r] [-u] [-e] [<path> ...]]
	[-mkdir [-p] <path> ...]
	[-moveFromLocal <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-moveToLocal <src> <localdst>]
	[-mv <src> ... <dst>]
	[-put [-f] [-p] [-l] [-d] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-renameSnapshot <snapshotDir> <oldName> <newName>]
	[-rm [-f] [-r|-R] [-skipTrash] [-safely] <src> ...]
	[-rmdir [--ignore-fail-on-non-empty] <dir> ...]
	[-setfacl [-R] [{-b|-k} {-m|-x <acl_spec>} <path>]|[--set <acl_spec> <path>]]
	[-setfattr {-n name [-v value] | -x name} <path>]
	[-setrep [-R] [-w] <rep> <path> ...]
	[-stat [format] <path> ...]
	[-tail [-f] <file>]
	[-test -[defsz] <path>]
	[-text [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-touch [-a] [-m] [-t TIMESTAMP ] [-c] <path> ...]
	[-touchz <path> ...]
	[-truncate [-w] <length> <path> ...]
	[-usage [cmd ...]]

Generic options supported are:
-conf <configuration file>        specify an application configuration file
-D <property=value>               define a value for a given property
-fs <file:///|hdfs://namenode:port> specify default filesystem URL to use, overrides 'fs.defaultFS' property from configurations.
-jt <local|resourcemanager:port>  specify a ResourceManager
-files <file1,...>                specify a comma-separated list of files to be copied to the map reduce cluster
-libjars <jar1,...>               specify a comma-separated list of jar files to be included in the classpath
-archives <archive1,...>          specify a comma-separated list of archives to be unarchived on the compute machines

The general command line syntax is:
command [genericOptions] [commandOptions]
ExitValue: 255

Result

You have now:
Solution

paragraphs.title: 11 - Familiarize yourself with the operations available with the hdfs dfs command

msg.data:
Usage: hadoop fs [generic options]
	[-appendToFile <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-cat [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-checksum <src> ...]
	[-chgrp [-R] GROUP PATH...]
	[-chmod [-R] <MODE[,MODE]... | OCTALMODE> PATH...]
	[-chown [-R] [OWNER][:[GROUP]] PATH...]
	[-copyFromLocal [-f] [-p] [-l] [-d] [-t <thread count>] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-copyToLocal [-f] [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-count [-q] [-h] [-v] [-t [<storage type>]] [-u] [-x] [-e] <path> ...]
	[-cp [-f] [-p | -p[topax]] [-d] <src> ... <dst>]
	[-createSnapshot <snapshotDir> [<snapshotName>]]
	[-deleteSnapshot <snapshotDir> <snapshotName>]
	[-df [-h] [<path> ...]]
	[-du [-s] [-h] [-v] [-x] <path> ...]
	[-expunge]
	[-find <path> ... <expression> ...]
	[-get [-f] [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-getfacl [-R] <path>]
	[-getfattr [-R] {-n name | -d} [-e en] <path>]
	[-getmerge [-nl] [-skip-empty-file] <src> <localdst>]
	[-head <file>]
	[-help [cmd ...]]
	[-ls [-C] [-d] [-h] [-q] [-R] [-t] [-S] [-r] [-u] [-e] [<path> ...]]
	[-mkdir [-p] <path> ...]
	[-moveFromLocal <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-moveToLocal <src> <localdst>]
	[-mv <src> ... <dst>]
	[-put [-f] [-p] [-l] [-d] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-renameSnapshot <snapshotDir> <oldName> <newName>]
	[-rm [-f] [-r|-R] [-skipTrash] [-safely] <src> ...]
	[-rmdir [--ignore-fail-on-non-empty] <dir> ...]
	[-setfacl [-R] [{-b|-k} {-m|-x <acl_spec>} <path>]|[--set <acl_spec> <path>]]
	[-setfattr {-n name [-v value] | -x name} <path>]
	[-setrep [-R] [-w] <rep> <path> ...]
	[-stat [format] <path> ...]
	[-tail [-f] <file>]
	[-test -[defsz] <path>]
	[-text [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-touch [-a] [-m] [-t TIMESTAMP ] [-c] <path> ...]
	[-touchz <path> ...]
	[-truncate [-w] <length> <path> ...]
	[-usage [cmd ...]]

Generic options supported are:
-conf <configuration file>        specify an application configuration file
-D <property=value>               define a value for a given property
-fs <file:///|hdfs://namenode:port> specify default filesystem URL to use, overrides 'fs.defaultFS' property from configurations.
-jt <local|resourcemanager:port>  specify a ResourceManager
-files <file1,...>                specify a comma-separated list of files to be copied to the map reduce cluster
-libjars <jar1,...>               specify a comma-separated list of jar files to be included in the classpath
-archives <archive1,...>          specify a comma-separated list of archives to be unarchived on the compute machines

The general command line syntax is:
command [genericOptions] [commandOptions]
ExitValue: 255

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
